name: places/ChIJJZkaUZBZwokRRljt4wKOV6E
formattedAddress: 60 Washington Square S, New York, NY 10012, USA
adrFormatAddress: 60 Washington Square S, New York, NY 10012-1019, USA

originalText.text: I wish I had read these reviews. I was seduced by the branding and the idea of my daughter spending time at NYU. She was in the YouTube  camp and it was promised that they would get to use the green screen for their projects and while they were showed the screen they never used it, the teachers said it would be too difficult to set it up. My daughter had experience editing video and so was able to do the assignment of making two 3 min videos,  which was the only activity from 9 to 3 for four days, with no direction, no templates, no new skills. Recess was just hanging out. She shared a class with the minecraft and roblox students and was jealous that they got to play games. She showed me her video, which would have been decent if someone had her record herself in a quieter place. The classroom was so loud I am not sure how she was able to concentrate. I gave it 2 stars because my daughter did have fun spending time making a video and a new friend. All said though, agree that it is very overpriced for having unprepared instructors  that didnt seem to care much about their students' learning new skills.

originalText.text: I wish I had seen some of the reviews here before I sent my son to a Lavner game coding camp on the Lower East Side in 2022. It was pretty pricey, but the hours and description worked for us so we went with it. I carefully read their COVID policy ahead of time and it seemed good. But then the Friday before the camp I also called to confirm. They explained that masking and vaccines were no longer required nor was testing (which it had said in the description), but said my kid could eat his lunch outside as their one concession. I asked if they had HEPA filters and/or open windows and they said they had central air and could open windows if requested. I said, I would prefer that. They agreed to do so. Then over the weekend e-mailed me that it was too hot to open the windows so they had no plans for ventilation. I'm sure you can guess where this is going - our kid, after 2 and a half years,  got COVID.  Apparently there was kid there on the first day who was coughing, sneezing and not wearing a mask. They didn't open any windows. They didn't isolate and test or call home. He stayed the whole day but was gone the rest of the week. It turned our household upside down. I wrote to the camp immediately once we got a positive test. No response from them. Not even an acknowledgement that they got my note. Not to mention, my child really learned nothing from the camp. No real lessons or projects to point to. We would have been better off, spent less money, learned more and been healthier if we had just opted for Outschool.

originalText.text:
I was extremely disappointed with this camp. My son attended the Pokémon Trainers Camp this year and was essentially put in a room with other kids to play the TCG software all day. There was no instruction, barely supervision, and zero structure. They were even out in a room with another camp group with different curriculum. (Spoiler: those kids didn’t do anything but sit in front of a screen all day too)

I paid $800 for my son to do exactly what he would have done at home for a week. He learned absolutely nothing new or even what was promised in the camp description.

The only good thing that came out of the week was that he met a new friend. Otherwise, as one reviewer said, it’s glorified babysitting.

Extreme disappointment is probably an understatement.

originalText.text: Most of the other reviews are lying. Only one or two of Camp Lavner's STEM classes have good curriculums, the rest are terrible and this whole operation is just a regular day camp except less fun and way more expensive. The STEM outcome of these courses is negligible. Save your money and send your kids to a normal day camp, or choose one that is more reputable in science if your goal is STEM enrichment.

originalText.text: My son loved the national Minecraft tournament last summer and he can't wait to attend the new national Roblox tournament this year.  He's already practicing roblox after school to get ready for camp and is determined that the NYU team will win the tournament this summer!
